page.title: 08BROOMFIELD CHURCH
page.content: The oldest part of the present church is the south chancel wall which has a small doorway. It was probably built before 1320. The tower of Broomfield Church was built in 1440. The south side of the nave and the chancel arch and porch were rebuilt and the aisle was added in the 16th century. The east wall and window were put there in the 19th century. The large trees protect the church from the north and east winds. The beautiful wagon roofs of the nave and aisle are of a similar style.Above the south door are the royal arms of Queen Anne dated 1714. Andrew Crosse, one of the earliest scientists to study electrical energy is buried in the church. The carved bench-ends dated 1522 are by Simon Werman, who also carved the bench-ends in Trull church.
